This is now my neighborhood hangout!  They must lace their fish + chips with cocaine because they are extremely addicting!   D4 has a weekend brunch that is always packed, and dinner here is busy every night.  That must say something about the restaurant...and I'm proud that such a great restaurant is in my Streeterville neighborhood!

The decor here is massively confusing. Rustic, modern, cozy, open and spacious Irish pub? ...... exactly.  Huh? Large drink menu with Streeterville prices.  Who ever thought Guinness and champagne would go together?  Well, they don't.  Not impressed with this drink.  I prefer my Black and Tan. Please note:  The patio closes promptly at 12:00 Midnight.  We were booted inside at 12:02.

I'm surprised at the negative comments about the service here, as I've always been served very quickly and by very friendly staff who will stop to chat and share a joke.  The drink selection is huge - though I have to say that I'm not entirely convinced it was actually Hoegaarden I got when I asked for it, it tasted funny - and they have Delirium Tremens beer (and, brilliantly, the coasters to match with the pink elephants on them).  Nondescript interior - half a pub-alike, but with an enormous amount of space, and then industrial ductwork exposed and painted maroon. Or, methinks, not painted but just left to be maroon. Either way - not my kind of decor.  BUT here's the killer - their happy hour boasts $1 sliders and half price appetizers which is an absolute bargain as they are stonking good sliders and the food's delicious. I'd eat here at full price but have ended up grabbing cheap eats before going to a movie at AMC, which is perfect.

Service: BIG sticks up their assess. Came both times with groups after work on *weeknights* (not Friday) and the hosts seemed appalled that we didn't have reservations and *gasp* had more people coming later?! to their 5/6 empty LARGE bar/pub. Seriously, be a little more happy to see people asking to spend money on food and booze in your food and booze establishment.  Food: Fantastic, actually. The chicken fingers are drool worthy, and they have some pretty decent happy hour specials on weeknights. Beer: Very respectable selection on draft and even more respectable in bottles. Great belgian selection, and lots of props for good selection of midwest microbrews on tap and in bottles. Waitstaff could be a bit more attentive about noticing near-empties/empties and asking about beer #2-3 and 4... Again, please encourage me to drink beer and give you more money...

Worst service ever.  We were a large party and they got our order wrong.  The waiter did not check back - even after we told him the order was wrong (and it was not a tough order).  Worst of all, after getting the order wrong, they did not rectify the situation and only reduced the bill by 90 cents.  Talk about insulting!   When we spoke to a manager he said that next time we came in we could ask for him and he'd send over one drink..as it we would ever go back after that service!
Good prices, great environment, good food, good service.  Im a big fan of this place

Seriously guys, what's with all the negativity?!! This place is such a hidden gem downtown!! It's not touristy, considering the area, and has a freakin' ahhmazing beer selection, with alcohol percentages listed to each one. ***Baked Brie and Apples** the stuff dreams are made of and totally worth the little extra time to wait while it bakes up in the oven..served with grapes and crustini bread..Absolutely perfect, hands down.  Service is always very attentive, although there is one waiter there who is a little skittish and clutzy, but he seems to be the only one working when we go there so I can understand. The place is dark and cozy, with way high ceilings and dark wood and large leather booths. Miss Erica highly recommends!!

Went on a Friday night and it was pretty empty....not a good sign. But it was within stumbling distance to the BFF's place and they had food. We were seated very quickly and our skeevy, yet polite server came by after a few minutes to take our order.  We seemed to be one of the only all girl groups there (more of a date spot imo), and our waiter seemed to be in creepy stare heaven. Get out much dude?  That aside, the beer selection was pretty good (tad overpriced) and the food was pretty solid. My friend had a yummy veggie sandwich, which I managed to steal bites from when she wasn't looking, and I had the chips that were good and cheap. When I asked where the restrooms were server dude made some odd comment about my hair looking great and winked. What a weirdo... The food and location make it a yes, but the lack of clientele and confused ambiance (gatropub/cafe/night spot/happy hour hot spot) make it just  another generic after-work spot with a random playlist. Add the creepy guy and it makes this place a socially awkward teen trying to "find" himself. Skip it...

I used to be a D4-hater when it first opened around the corner, mostly cause I'm just a hater.  But after a few late nights and happy hours, I have been converted.  The food is pretty good (I usually get a bunch of sliders) and the happy hour deals are solid.  The beer selection is great and at $6 a beer, I guess they're sort of decently-priced.  It's kind of busy right after work, but I've gone a few Saturday nights and it wasn't too bad.  The service I've had has always been great.  Good place.

I went here a few days ago with a friend to grab a drink. The beer is reasonably priced, and they do carry a nice selection of beer. We had the chips which appear to be homemade, and they also seemed like they were old and stale. The dip that came with the chips was good.  The decor is something of a mystery. Because when you gaze upon D4 you get the feeling that it is cozy and all Irish and publy. But then they play traditional irish music such as Madonna and other hits from the 80's. Which I never knew the Irish loved New Wave and other forms of 80's music so much. But apparently Madonna is a Saint of Potato's in Ireland so that would explain as much.

I like this place because it's a clean, handsome, & bright spot to grab a reasonably priced bite to eat in Streeterville.  Perfect for pre-AMC theater movie dates (it's right around the block).   I've been here about 5 times (3 lunches and 2 dinners). I have to agree with other reviewers that the service and food can be inconsistent.  My first burger was great; second visit it was overcooked and dry.  My first French dip was phenomenal! Second time, the bread was stale and meat super-fatty.  I just had the corn beef sandwich last weekend and was like A+  (ask for extra mustard on the side, they only put a weak smear on the bread)... next time I go I'm ordering the same just to see how it will come out the second time.  The chicken pot pie was pretty good too. Service:  B+   friendly but sometimes hard to catch their attention.  Where do they disappear to?  Food: B+   seems like you're rolling the dice but when it's good it's good. Beer: A great selection, the Guinness tastes right

This place has serious identity issues.  Is it an Irish pub, is it a gastropub, is it a hip nightspot?  I think D4 looks really pretty and they obviously put a lot of effort into the appearance, I just with that effort extended to the menu.  Then again, it could just be my mistake in thinking they were trying to be a restaurant.  Who knows?  The place just doesn't have an identity.

I love D4. Lunch is very iffy though -- hit or miss service.  But happy hours are great. Good beer selection (and fights, too!), and half-priced appetizers. When it's cold outside, they have the fireplaces roaring. When it's warm, the patio is open.

Forgive this treason.  But I LOVE the pizza here.  It's a small chicago style pizza with a perfect thick-but-not-too-thick crust, baked with just the right amount of cheese that actually gets golden brown and then they put the stewed tomatoes on top, after it comes out.  It's not fussy, and just right for two people who are also filling up on the great beers available and I think it's about $10. We come here about once a month when doing a movie night at the ACM 21.  We'll get down to the theater 90 minutes before the show, get our tickets and then go have a few drinks and some food at D4 (WAY WAY better than the food at Lucky Strike right at the movies).  In addition to the pizza, we love the mini blue burgers on brioche with blue cheese, and the smoked salmon plate.  We usually sit at the bar and have never had anything but the best service.  It can get a little rowdy and loud at times but it's got to have some kind of Irish authenticity right?   This is not the place to come for a cozy Irish pub experience.  There really isn't anything pub-like about it.  It's too cavernous and too much thought was placed into the ambiance.  But for the neighborhood it's a great choice, better than Lucky Strike, and better than P.J. Clarks.

Let me start by saying I'm very biased towards this place.  I was the 30th resident in the Streeter building that sits on top of D4, and I anxiously awaited it to open for months.  I spent a lot of time here eating and drinking.  The pulled pork sandwich is the best I've had.  The Jameson buff wings are great, and the salmon is delicious.  This place has outstanding pub food.  The beer menu is extensive with lots of good imports including my favorite, Hoeegarden on tap.  Definitely not a place for a friday/saturday night, but a good spot for weekday enjoyment.

Crashed a going away party that one of my friend's was throwing. She had reserved a section of the bar, got bracelets and an open bar special.  I came late with another friend so relied on my sauced friends to provide me with bevs; they did not disappoint.   I didn't eat, but there were a lot of good looking young professional types and the place is huge so you never feel cramped and there is plenty of room to sit.  The outdoor patio was huge, it was 80 degrees that day and every last seat was taken. I'll have to remember this place as a great happy hour spot for summer.

I like their fat, juicy burgers on brioche.  Even well done, there is meat juice dripping down my hands.  They are huge and messy to eat, but half a burger is more than enough for a meal.  It's a bit heavy, but the meat is flavorful and well-seasoned, so I don't regret spending a day's worth of calories here. I always get fries with my burger, even if they are too skinny and too dry for me. One time I ordered a Cobb Salad.  I've stuck with the burgers since then.

I love that D4 not only has a slew of beers to choose from, it also has a pretty decent wine selection, including one of my new favorites.  The food is good, and recently they've rolled out some happy hour app specials, which is definitely welcome.   When stuck for a place to go after work, this is usually where my co-workers and I end up.  It can get a little expensive, but who really wants to pound drinks with co-workers?  There's a nice little outside seating area that I'm excited to test out this summer.

I finally made it to D4. I was looking forward to a somewhat Americanized Irish bar with a big beer list and some tasty vittles. And I pretty much got it. Upon the arrival of one of my truly Irish friends, he encouraged me to try my first Beamish, which I really liked. We got appetizers which were...okay. I mean, for a "gastropub"-type bar they were probably mid-range of "prettified" munchies. I had to try the BBQ slider things (based on reviews here) and I concur that they are indeed quite tasty. The weird brie and apple tart thing was kinda gooey and bland. The "black and bleu" sliders were pretty well-done, which just isn't really necessary, given how small they are.  The service was...decent. I had arrived first out of my group of 4 friends and I sat at the table for a good 10-15 minutes before anyone asked me if I'd like anything to drink. However, when we gained another person our server easily transferred us to a larger table, so that was cool.  The only thing that turned me off about this place - and turned me off in a BIG way - was that when I arrived at about 5:45-6pm on a Friday night and got seated...the place was CRAWLING with strollers and small children. I get that it's Streeterville and there are families everywhere. I understand it was still sorta early (even though Happy Hour is from 4-6 and I've never really thought 3-year olds and Happy Hours went together, by any stretch of semantics or the imagination), but...damn. I'm at a bar, I'm going to drink. There will most likely be foul language and inappropriate conversation for certain types of adults, much less little ears. So when I asked the hostess if there would be another table away from small ones, it wasn't because I don't like kids or that I was planning on table-top dancing; it was just because I figured that in a bar (in the US, anyway; I know things are different in the UK and Europe, but this place is in Chicago), with my group of friends, maybe sitting directly next to a toddler and a baby out with Mom and Grandma wouldn't be the happiest place for anyone involved. As it turns out, there were no other tables available at the time, so I accepted the table and got the stink eye from Grandma as she burped Little Junior for 20 minutes while I waited an eternity for some blessed alcohol. So, if you're in the area and you'd like a pretty good pint, head on in. If you're there during Happy Hour, be prepared to share it with the kiddies. If not, I'm sure a little table-top dancing never hurt anyone...seriously...

To me an Irish pub needs to have that great dungeon like quality -- you know the dark wood, the dim lights, and maybe random pictures pubs in Ireland, a framed picture of james joyce and poster that says "hurling, the irish sport of champions".  But I guess not every Irish pub can be like my favorite college hangout the James Joyce. This place isn't all that bad.  The atmosphere isn't bad and more importantly the beer selection is above average -- but pricey in my opinion.  The one redeeming quality of this D4 is definitely their burgers, and for those of us that love sliders it's is excellent.  I recommend going to D4 for their happy hour (4-6pm) when they have dollar sliders and mini pulled pork sandwiches -- you shouldn't be disappointed.  Oh and their food is quite good, and especially their Shepherd's pie.

I'd seriously like to say this place should be called Douche to the 4th Power or something equally snarky, because let's face it, I'm a bit of a bitch.  Is that why I don't get as many funnies as I wish I did?  My bitchiness aside, this place isn't all that terrible.   I worked in a gallery at River East Art Center, so D4 was a convenient place to go when the art world made me want to slit my wrists, and trust me, sometimes it does.  I need liquor to make me forget my woes.  Drinks are pretty standard in strength and price, and they have a pretty decent beer selection.   Foodwise I've had the French onion soup which is not at the top, nor the bottom of my scale of French onion awesomeness.  I've also had the pulled pork and burger sliders.  Pulled pork ones are definitely good, and the burger ones are ok, though they come with bleu cheese on it which I ate anyway because I was obviously drunk.  Next time I'll skip the moldcheese.   I wouldn't go out of my way to visit Douche the 4th, but if I find myself subbing for someone at the gallery or hitting up an opening, or possibly stepping into some kind of portal that drops you into Streeterville, I'd come back.

Large place, large beer selection, tacky music. Lots of seating so it would be good for groups. A group of us came here at the recommendation of our friends from Northwestern Medical School. It was a Thursday night and it wasn't crowded at all. What's with the music though? Mainstream and pop-ish. It didn't really fit the atmosphere of a Irish pub. I don't drink beer so I had 3 shots. Shots were $6. I had a Buttery Nipple, Mud Slide, and Black Russian. The Mud Slide and Black Russian were stiff shots but the Buttery Nipple was just way too sweet and I felt like I was drinking butterscotch. They had a specialty martini menu; one of the fruity martinis was pretty strong.  Our friends ordered Hoegaarden beers. One of our friends ordered one with Black Currant liquor and Apple Cider? I hate the taste of beer but this tasted like candy.  It was tolerable. These Irish pubs - they're all the same to me, so this one gets an "A-OK" rating.

We visited D4 Friday night around 5:30.  It was our first time there, but we were in the neighborhood and the place was crowded, which can be a positive sign, so we gave it a shot and were seated immediately.  Upon being seated, the spotty service quickly became evident:  waiting an extended time to be greeted by our server, being asked to share a menu because they didn't print enough, and being asked what we wanted to drink immediately upon having the drink/food menu handed to us. The drink menu is decent and competitively priced --they have the standard macro brew swill but also some domestic and imported craft beers. The food is really hit-or-miss.  Before 6pm, they have $1 pulled-pork sandwiches that were surprisingly good, especially since pulled-pork isn't traditional fare at an "Irish" cafe. The menu didn't mention the happy-hour special, and unfortunately the server didn't either, so there another strike against the service here.  The only reason we found out about the special is that we ordered a serving of the pulled-pork, which was three sandwiches, and asked if we could add a fourth for an extra charge.  At this point the server said the burgers were a dollar each as long as it was before 6pm. For main courses, we ordered bangers & mash and chicken pot pie.  The bangers were decent, mashed potatoes & gravy was good, but the chicken pot pie tasted like it came out of your grocer's freezer.  On a positive note, the entrees were moderately priced at around $14 This place is decent for happy-hour appetizers and drinks, but I recommend staying away from the entrees, and I hope the serving staff and management can print up extra menus and greet guests more expediently.

I want to like this place...afterall, it should stand as a refreshing alternative to the bowling alley or PJ Clarkes before a movie at River East.  However, I've been three times now, and it's been pretty inconsistent. The service has been pretty good and the beer list is decent...so far so good.  Yet, aside from a beer, I'm there for the food and this is where it gets iffy.  Not particularly bad, not particularly great, though a bit expensive for what it is.  The real problem is that when you have a menu of pretty standard fare...like Sheppard's pie...unless you make it clear you've messed with it...it had better be a standard Sheppard's pie. I know places like to make things their own, and add a little zing...but usually they make that clear on the menu...and usually it's an attempt at making a classic more interesting, not just a really poor attempt like they don't know what they're doing.  My last order was indeed the Sheppard's pie and it was basically a bland wet stew of hamburger and veg with a dollup of unbrowned and unappetizing mashed potatoes in the middle. That's kind of typical of what I've eaten there thus far, and I'm disappointed.  It's an Irish pub, and I'd like some decent Irish pub fare.  Otherwise, the place is alright, and I will continue to go there for a beer and a burger before my movies...I'll simply ignore their attempt at the whole ethnic cuisine thing and concentrate more on the beer...and it'll do just fine.

I've been there on St. Patrick's day and when it is not. St. Patrick's day is too busy for obvious reasons and the service suffers a bit. They were also serving Bud Light which I hate - it tastes like skunked Coors Light. No Miller Lite - my choice of light beer for long day of drinking. Anyway on other days, the service is very friendly and patient. They have excellent fries - thin and crisp. Also they have a decent selection of beers.

I work around the area, and have been to D4 a number of times since the first week they've been open. It has the perfect balance of great space, but an intimate atmosphere where you can talk with people next to you. My favorite place to sit with big groups is this round booth they have towards the back. It's like a giant circle leather booth that's really comfortable and perfect for hanging out. The beer menu is awesome, because it has a number of great beer mixes. I've had pretty much everything on the menu (except for a a few of the salads), but all the food I've had has been top quality. Every time I go there, I'm torn between the Prime Rib French Dip or the Fish and Chips. The waiters are always cool and helpful. I remember a time when someone I was with dropped her appetizer. Our waiter brought out a fresh one at no cost even though we didn't ask for one. This place is all about attention to their customers. Brendan McNeil (one of the owners, and one of the guys who opened Lizzie McNeil's in Streeterville) is usually around the restaraunt, and even posts up at the hosts stand to seat people himself once in a while. It's a really cool place to grab a beer and a few appetizers with friends, and chill out by the fireplace. I'm glad it's not packed shoulder to shoulder like next door neighbor Timmy O'Toole's is...crowded enough, but not stuffy. It's a good change of pace.

Went her for brunch - there were two other couples in the whole restaurant and our service sucked balls. I think our server was super baked out of his mind - and to each his own but maybe he should have been working at Jimmy Johns. My husband asked about some drinks on the menu and the server had to go ask the bartender every time what was in them. I mean, it was their staple Irish drinks on the menu - and they had TWO ingredients (beer mixed with something else). He also didn't know what bangers and rashers were (which were on the menu as a side to just about everything). We asked the hostess if he was new, she paused long enough garble "NO" flipped her hair and walked away.  Our food came out one at a time after about 20 minutes (hubby had eggs, I had a lox-like dish). It took us 5-6 min to track the server down for silverware. Another 10 for salt and pepper.  They are plenty of other expensive Irish pubs in the city - don't go to this one.

My company had our holiday party here and I wish it hadn't been. For starters they only house white wine they had available was a Chardonnay and I was really looking for a Pinot. But I got over that real quick. The food that was served was just a downright disappointment. The person who planned the party said that the food was really good. Um not so much. I think the best thing I had was the veggies and ranch dressing, and even the ranch was a little funky. I was excited to see spinach dip available because I love spinach dip but it had NO flavor whatsoever.  I do want to mention that the space we were given for our party was pretty lame. All we got was a little corner of the bar that they roped off and only a couple of tables and areas to sit.  It was a free party and all so I just drank my chardonnay ate my celery and carrots and moved on once the party was over. I will not be back in the near future unless my company decides to throw another party there and I hope they don't.
Not the friendliest place around. We asked the server for a menu and she replied, NOPE kitchens closed. Nice! The staff seems angry.  Won't be heading back anytime soon.

So on the side of my Yelp [age, it says "People Who Viewed This Also Viewed..." and includes Timothy O'Toole's and Lizzie McNeill's", which is befitting as D4 is another one of those lame Chicago 'Irish' bars.   But D4 isn't O'Toole's lame, maybe like Grand Lux Cafe lame  Streeterville, along Illinois and Grand, is a growing young boy and businesses like D4 would do wonders for that four block soulless stretch from Fairbanks to Navy Pier.  Maybe open up a Chipotle and be done with it.   Fish and chips are pretty good.  Pulled pork sliders taste like rubberbands in dinner rolls.  The server guy was quite attentive to the party of 15 plus and I felt bad for him having to deal with us losers that really should have gone to the Golden Nugget.  With all the couples coming in, maybe from the Streeter or Holmes Place, this place reminded me of that bar Ally McBeal and gang went to after work.

The food here is REALLY good for a pub/bar.  Well above average and good for the price range.  Also, if you are a beer fan, this is the place.  Over 80 beers on the menu, plus quite a few wines. One negative is I would like to see them add more bar/drink specials, as they have a huge bar/lounge area in the front that would be great for small groups.   As for the positives: Beer Tasting:  for $7, you get 3, 6 oz beers off a specials list Food:  Pulled Pork sliders, Shephard's Pie, Regular sliders, Shrimp, Red Pepper and French Onion Soup, Chicken Sandwich, Sunday Brunch Happy Hour:  $1 sliders from 4-6.  Makes up for no beer happy hour...

If you're looking for a clean basic pub in this neighborhood, D4 is a good choice.  Decent burgers.  Nothing Irish about the place.  Good for a group, as we did before going to a nearby movie.  Kid friendly.  Just a good standard pub.

Like some other reviewers have mentioned, the food here is hit and miss.  Some dishes are great, while others are just okay.  But the atmosphere is really laid-back and welcoming.  They have a beautiful bar too.

I live really close to D4 and I'm really trying to like it, but the food just isnt that good.  I've eaten there a number of times now and the inconsistency is killin' it for me.  This past weekend I ordered their Black & Bleu mini-burgers and they were AWESOME! So good  I was fantasizing about them.  So I just went out and got some and they were...not that good.  What happened?  That always happens, someone orders something great and I order the same thing and it's medicore, or vice versa.   What a shame.  It's close,  the atmosphere is very easy-going, the people are super friendly and they have alcohol, maybe the trick is to not order food it's a Hit or Miss every time.
This place has spectacular, friendly service. It is clean with a variety of beer and pub food. Perfect for anything, lunch, dinner, just drinks, groups or just a few.

I have been here about 5 times or so. The experience has been different every time.  It looks like a typical irish pub. The bartenders are really friendly and pretty efficient. There happy hour food discounts are GREAT- you can get a lot of food for like $5. (The food is really good too!)  The problem is the servers. If you don't want to sit at the bar, you have to have a waitress- which personally kind of annoys me, but most people must prefer it or something. Anyway- the last time I was there, we had a group of about 10 people and they COMPLETELY messed up the bill. (A couple hundred dollar mess up....) They didn't apologize and figuring out how to give people their money back seemed way too complicated.  I would meet someone here for a drink after work or something, but I wouldn't plan on spending your whole night here. And sit at the bar.

I took a big leap of faith by throwing a surprise birthday party at a place where I had never been. What was I thinking?! But, I have to say I didn't learn any lessons the hard way, as the party was a huge hit. I really have to thank D4 and its amazing staff for everything. From the first conversation with Debbie at D4, I felt comfortable that they would be accommodating with all my requests and would make every effort to ensure a good time. Debbie made the planning aspect very easy. And, on the day of the party, when I was stopping by delivering cake, decorations, etc., everyone at D4 made sure that I felt comfortable that things would go smoothly. Of the 50 or so people that showed, not one had any complaint. In fact, everyone had only the best things to say: the food was great, the service was great, the atmosphere was great, everything was great. And, I have to second those compliments. Rarely am I impressed with bar food. The food there was delicious: chicken fingers, sliders, spinach dip, shrimp skewers, crabcakes. We have some picky eaters in our crew, and not one person didn't love the food. It was quality. The drinks were good, no skimping on booze. And, our waitress (Marsha, I believe) was a saint. She was like Urlacher on the football field. I mean, whenever you needed a drink, there she was. She must have a twin! No one had to wait long for anything. What great service. As opposed to at least one review on yelp, I thought the music was fine. Most of us are over 30... so, we liked some of the throwbacks. But, there were some in the group younger, and no one had any problems with the music. As far as atmosphere, I also saw on yelp an issue with it being stale according to a yelper or two. Really, again, no one had any issue here. I actually was thankful that the space was clean, new, open, and felt that despite the newness, there was a charm to it. I have taken issue in the past to some sterile spaces, as a lot of new places in the city lack the charm of some of the older establishments. But, I don't believe that D4 fits into any staleness category whatsoever. I think it is quite telling that 3 weeks after the fact I still have people saying how good the food was, how nice the people were, and that overall, they had a great time. That says a lot. One final note, nothing at D4 was outrageous in terms of price. We really had an amazing party at a reasonable value. I could not have asked for anything more. Thank you, D4.

I was torn between a 2 and a 3 star rating for this one.  Here goes: The ambiance is decidedly NOT Irish. OK, they have a fireplace, a big wooden bar and some stools, but it is a huge open place that oozes "corporate."  Whatever. We went on Friday for HH and the service was good when we had a large group. But as the numbers dwindled so did our waiter's attention.  In the end it was three of us and he asked us to move around so he could open up one of the tables... That was fine until we asked for the check and he overcharged us by 30$. He fixed the check, but we still think he screwed us.  The food was Hit or Miss. I had the mini blue cheese burgers. I wouldn't get them again. They were so well done that I couldn't taste the meat, and there was so little blue cheese that it was hardly noticable.  The hubby had some sort of sausage sandwich that was good though. Go figure? Anyhoo, if I just wanted beer with friends- 3 stars. If I wanted food or the real Irish pub type of place- 2 stars

Nice looking bar but what is up with the 30 foot ceiling? I felt like I was in the batcave.(Maybe cuz I had just watched Batman around the corner)The food was not very good and the service was subpar but they had a really nice selection of beers.Not my best option for sports either as they do not have many TVS and the atmosphere just is not a Cubs Nation type.

I'm conflcted.  D4 has good food.  Really good food in my opinion, especially compared to our mainstay work lunch hole, O'Tooles which is a block or two away.   Take away the food, though, and everything else is kind of crappy.  It feels somewhat pretentious, the music is awful (unless you like Phil Collins Megamix), and the service is subpar. If I could go there with my order placed ahead of time, put on headphones and blinders, it might be a 4 or 5 star joint.

I've been here for lunch a few times, and am always thrown off by the decor. It feels like there is too much space filled with some cozy furniture, and no one really knows how to capitalize on the tall ceilings.  The pulled pork sandwich is good, and that is the reason it's what most people get when we go. Last time I tried the chicken salad, and those cooks didn't put ANY salt or pepper in that salad. I had to also keep reminding myself that there were supposed to be some grapes and nuts in the mix as well.  So I'm not thrilled by D4, and I really hope things change and get better, because the servers working there are really nice and the location is a good one.  Now I'm going to find out what D4 means.

Pretty standard faux-irish pub (a disturbingly common trend throughout the city) with mediocre food and mediocre service.   I got the chicken sandwich which was dry and overdone so it became a pricey BLT.  My wife's cobb salad was a lot of toppings without much actual salad.   This felt like a burger/beer type of joint.  Stray at your own peril.

I checked out D4 a few nights ago - met some friends for dinner and a few drinks. The food we had was very good - certainly no complaints.  Our server, Shannon, was excellent, and offererd great suggestions and was just attentive enough but never hovered, and she accomodated our request for a separate check for the two of us who had to leave a little early. I will say, though, that there's not much that makes this an Irish Cafe, aside from some of the tchochkes they have sprinkled around.  I also thought having the fireplace going when it was 85 outside was unneccesary - but overall, I enjoyed D4.

I met up with a college friend here for after work drinks/dinner and was expecting a loud, raucous bar scene.  Fortunately, it wasn't too crowded and the tables were spaced far enough from each other that you can hold a conversation without having to lean over or shout over the next guy next to you. We were seated by the fireplace section where there were two low stools and a cushy window seat.  Our waitress was excellent although I'm not quite sure what I can say to the bartender who poured my Guinness.  It took awhile for the head to settle and I guess they didn't hold my pint at an angle when s/he poured it from the tap... Anyway, since we were at an Irish bar, I was in the mood for something along the lines of Irish/British food so I opted for the Shepherd's pie.  I received my plate and was expecting a pie shaped creation with the meat on the bottom and the mash potatoes on top.  However, it was basically ground beef, carrots , and peas with about 2 scoops of mash potatoes on top. Nothing spectacular because all I cared about was my Guinness. Although, I have to say our service was excellent.  They made sure our water glasses were constantly filled, our waitress constantly checked up on us to make sure our food and drinks were ok and the second waiter asked how my Shepherd's pie was. Overall, the experience was pleasant other than the creepy guy who came by the window and made out with it...

Upon arriving, the hostess asked were we'd like to sit.  My dinner companion and I did a quick tour of the layout before deciding on a window seat in a cozier portion of the restaurant.  However, this was after noting that the high ceilings and low seating seemed to make the areas seem almost bare.  They would greatly benefit from incorporating more seating to fill the major gaps throughout the layout.   Our waiter was by far our most entertaining aspect of the dinner.  He was very blunt and often discouraged dishes that he didn't feel were up to par.  In fact, he told us the specials and then told us why he did not like them.  We got a real kick out of this.  He did, however, highlight the items he did enjoy.   He was all-around a good server.  The timing of the service was good.  We never waited long for another drink or the check. The bread was good and my soup was excellent.   I quickly sank my teeth into the beautifully assembled grilled chicken sandwich only to find disappointment.  There was absolutely no flavor.  It was very under seasoned and the chicken was overcooked and dry.  In fact, it was so poor that I had to send it back. Our hilarious server was very gracious about taking the order back.  When he came back, he told us he took it off the bill and offered to get me something else.  He then made a comment that the kitchen must be off their game because he'd received a number of complaints that evening.  My dinner companion's dish was successful so we stayed and enjoyed a few more drinks before departing.

I've been here twice now on different nights in the week/weekend. Always very nice evening out. The food is LOVELY! Drinks are quite pricey though. Service - hit or miss - one time the waitress took our order down wrong but the other time the waiter was very attentive and funny. Nice atmosphere and worth trying. I would definetely recommend the Chicken Pot Pie.  My Irish friend thought it was fairly authentic.

D4 -  I'M A HUGE FAN of this pub, and can give anyone reason to stop by Streeterville's hottest spot... for those of you who haven't been to D4 yet, here's my list of the goods: - BAR TYPE: Traditional, modern, classy Irish bar w/o a pretentious feel (definitely not cheesy and touristy, like Fado) - IMPRESSIVE, substantial BEER MENU including Beamish, Trumer Pils and varieties of Chimay  (menu also states alcohol content in every beer!) - FOOD is consistently excellent. Must try the Burgers, Filet Mignon entre, Blackened Salmon salad, Fish and Chips and Pulled Pork Sliders (It's all delicious!) Bread pudding is also very tastey... - PRICES -  food AND drink very reasonably priced, esp for the Streeterville area - STAFF - adorable and attentive. Owner of the bar is very charming, truly dedicated to his patrons - CROWD TYPE - attractive young professionals (esp after work), locals from the neighborhood  - AFTER WORK CROWD consists of employees from NBC Tower, PLAYBOY, CBS News, AON Corp., and other companies in the area - GREAT PLACE if you're single, going on a date, with a group of friends, or solo... a cozy place to bring ma & pa, even nana : ) - MUSIC TYPE -  Rock, Classic, Top 40, (good song selections) - BAR ATMOSPHERE is lofty and spacious, 2 fireplaces, hd tvs, plenty of seats at the bar (w/hooks for girls' purses :) I must add that the bathrooms are very clean!  - OUTDOOR SEATING - yes, there is ALFRESCO dining!  **OVERALL, really an impressive establishment...I have yet to find another pub that compares to the class and quality of D4's service, atmosphere, beer selection and food. (The house wine is excellent.)**

Ok, maybe it isn't authentic, but if I just think of it as a neighborhood bar that serves food, I like it. My wife and I have a place nearby and we finally wandered over for a late weekend dinner. The bar area was pretty full but the rest of the place was pretty empty. We sat at a table next to the famous fireplace. The draft beer selection was good and all the food we ordered was perfectly servicable. We tried an apple brie appetizer which was heart attack inducing but solid. My wife's french onion soup was acceptable. Her pear salad was on a tiny plate, but seemed fine. My cheeseburger with mushroom was fantastic. The burger was really the medium rare I ordered. Service was good, but then again there were only two other tables in our area for one waitress. I wouldn't venture across town for this place, but if you live in the area, check it out.

When I think of an Irish Pub, I think of small spaces, dark brown wooden walls, clusters of tables, and dimly lit lights.  When I stopped in yesterday to meet my friends for happy hour, I felt like I was walking into a galleria mall that was a tad bit too modern.  The ceilings must have been 30 feet high and the population density of tables to space was pretty low.  Based on first impressions, I don't know if I could see this as my Irish let-it-all-out-and-go-crazy type of drinking establishment.  Maybe I will have to try it another time. One advantages is that the beer list was excellent and the prices were not over the top.

This place is as authentically Irish as Lucky Charms and a Bennigan's. I guess if you're a suburban transplant, or tourist - it will hold some appeal.  Otherwise, it's only good for a quick after work drink. I didn't hate it, but that's because it was too bland to illicit any sort of response at all.  Lackluster and not worth your time.

My friends and I went here a couple of weeks ago and were pretty impressed with their thorough alcohol selection.  I had the beers with the highest alcohol contents and like them all quite a bit.  The place was cozy and the waiter was very entertaining.  He knew his beer and had very good recommendations.  I know I'll be back mostly because of the distance to my place and their selection.

I've been here a couple of times, and like it more and more every time.  The bar itself is very large-- it's a great place to have an after work happy hour since it's so spacious and a little off the beaten path.  It doesn't get packed like Sidebar or Townhouse.   The beer list is extensive--I love that they tell you the percentage of alcohol in all the beers.  The appetizers I've tried have all been pretty good, but the mini burgers really stand out.  They're a little bit spicy, and topped with blue cheese... delicious.  We couldn't help ourselves, and got an extra order, even though we had dinner reservations for later that night.

this place has a wonderful atmosphere - i love the high ceilings and fireplaces, the dim lighting, heavy chandeliers, and open feel.  i was here on a sunday night with friends when it was pretty quiet and not crowded, which made it feel all the cozier. being not all that hungry, though, i ordered a cobb salad, not the most pubbish food, so perhaps not the best pick.  it was unusual in that it had a brown mustard flavored dressing, which to me, wasn't all that pleasant, next to the big chunks of blue cheese.  i did have a bite of my friend's bread pudding, which was pretty heavenly.   i would go back again to try something besides a salad.  my friends enjoyed their fish 'n chips and pulled pork sandwich.

No, no, no, no. This place is no good.  I went to an event here for the holidays (actually after-but it was supposed to be a holiday party). It was very poorly executed. When I arrived I was ushered into a line for food. The food was set up at the door. So, you walked in from the cold and stood at the end of the line, right by the door and the food. The line went all the way to back of the bar and looped around. While in line people came around with appetizers, which turned out to be the same stuff on the table that we were waiting in line for. The food was not good. Chicken tenders loaded with grease, mini veggie sandwiches soo bland they were uneatable and mini burgers (which I didnt try as they came on rye bread, they ran out of buns). The event was not successful. Some people stood in line for over an hour, they ran out of food and it was impossible to get a drink while waiting in line.  I don't think I will be taking my business back here. I felt the food was awful and the lack of planning for an event with over 400 people was not a good reflection of the establishment.

I finally made my way over to this upscale Irish pub last night. It was a little more than half full on a Friday at 10ish. I had read the previous Yelper's reviews and knew I wanted a spot by the fireplace on such a treacherously cold night. Surpisingly the whole area was free and we were seated there immediately! With this, my cold tush is already impressed.  I had also read about all of the nice beer selections, so I let the waitress offer some suggestions. I decided upon the Chimay Red. Tasty beer! Plus it came with it's own glass. (Yes, I am easily impressed.)  The service was ok. We never had an empty glass, but then again the bar was empty(ish). It just seemed indifferent, which I have been experiencing a lot these days. Granted, she did chat it up with me while my friend was in the washroom, but I still wasn't wowed.  The atmosphere is nice enough. I like the chandeliers and the large booths. Clearly, the fireplace won me over as well. One big detraction from the setting was the lighting. It was so bright that I was practically squinting. I think this was caused by the large floor to ceiling windows that open onto Grand Ave. They need to either turn down the lights or cover the top section of windows, which were filthy anyway, with window valences.  I will probably come again and even recommend it to my guests. I wish I could give it 3.5 stars, but maybe I can bump it up to a 4 when I actually come to eat and not just drink.  IMPORTANT: Remember, the entrance is on Grand Ave, not Ohio like the address would suggest!

I would give it more like a 3.5 stars.  A couple of my friends and I went there after a late afternoon/early evening movie at AMC River East 21.  What is nice about this place is that it gives you another option than PJ's Clark.  So kudos for more options!  They have a GREAT beer selection and the menu is typical of Irish grub.  I did have a pulled pork sandwich ( I don't think you find too many of these in Ireland, but oh well...) It was fare...Not over the top fabulous, but good.  The space is nice and airy and of course like good ol' Chicago fashion..plenty of Tv's!  The best thing about this place is that another option in this area!

Pretty good for what it is. The food was better than standard bar food.  I had an excellent fish and chips, my bf had a cheese burger.   The cheese burger was a little dry, but my fish and chips was excellent.  Hand battered.  Not the frozen kind that's mushy inside.  They had different fries for each of our dishes.  My fish and chips got hand cut chunkier fries.  His burger got skinnier crispy fries. Beer lovers would really like the choices available.   Since I am not really a beer drinker, I cheated and had a beer that practically tasted like blackberry juice.  The decor is Irish pub like, but very new, spacious and clean.  I would go there again, definitely for the fish and chips.  It's in my neighborhood and so far the other places that I can get a burger is Charlie's at Navy Pier or Timmy O' Toole, neither is that nice.

We went there a couple days after it opened - it was full but not crowded.  Our waiter clearly did not know the food menu, did not know the beer/alcohol menu, and was poorly trained to say the least.  We waited 20 minutes for him to take our drink menu.  He couldn't answer any of our questions about the beer and then went on to say they had no more glasses for water so we would have to buy bottled water if we wanted water.  (we saw glasses of water being served at other tables all through the night.)  He would not take our food order even though we were more than ready to order at that point.  Another 15minutes before we got our drinks and he finally took our food order (again, couldn't answer questions about basic stuff - portion size, etc.)  They brought out my dessert first - the trifle - which was just cubed pound cake, berries, and cream.  Another 45minutes before we finally got our food.  The table next to us gave up and left.  The waiter apologized and said they were having issues all night because the kitchen was too small for the size of the menu and they only had two computers for the whole restaurant so the wait staff had to wait for a computer to open up to place orders.  My drink, one of the special mixed drinks (cranberry juice based) was bitter and disgusting - the whole table thought it was the worst drink they've ever drank.  I got some extra cranberry juice (which he charged me for) which helped decrease the bitterness.  The food - I got the wings, my companions got the chicken sandwich x 2 - was OK.  The wings were oily, chewy, and not very flavorful.  The chicken sandwich was good but cold by the time it came out. We were there for over two and a half hours - for mediocre food and terrible service.  No apologies from managers (as a matter of fact, no mangers were seen on the floor - the person at the front door said he had less power than a wait staff).  No offer to take things off our check, nothing.  Just excuses and annoyance from the clearly frustrated waiter. A few days later, another friend went there and reported back that their menu had been slashed - they got rid of most of the stuff on the food menu and now only a page of stuff remain.  That's probably for the better because people should go there for the drinks - not for the food.   Pros:  ambiance, location, big selection of beer Con:  undertrained staff, poor management, long wait time for food, mediocre food, bad service

I was utterly impressed by the coziness of this upscale Irish pub. The initial impression of a library is not necessarily a bad thing. Grab a booth by the window for people watching or stake out a booth by the fireplace for a more intimate setting. BTW, you can actually hear the person across from you. I visited D4 on a first date- and we both enjoyed it. And I agree with Vidya, this place doesn't feel like the standard smokey pub. The attentive service was a little touchy-feely but always ensured my pints were full. The menu really stresses the mixed beer varieties (black & tan, snake bite, etc.) but the bar "ran out" of Dunkelweizen on opening weekend! And you can check out the decent selection of Irish whiskeys and single malts if that's your flavor. The food menu adds a bit more flair than run of the mill bar food. FYI the Brie and amaretto-infused Apple "kettle" is uh-may-zing! The personal deep dish pizzas are also good, well perfect for me since I prefer a little less crust than Gino's or Lou's. Think more cheese instead of sauce for this variety. Also, the street address is deceptive. The entrance to D4 is actually off Grand even though the address is Ohio.

I'm really glad this place just opened, because this neighborhood generally lacks comfortable pubs that are not filled with tourists.  I don't know if it will stay that way, but so far I'm glad there is a place just across the street from home that has a comfortable pub atmoshphere and a very good beer selection. Other than the fries (which are really good - nice and crispy) I haven't had the food here so this review is more about the pub.  The bar feels cozy and personal, even though it is big and open and inside a modern glass highrise building.  There is a fireplace, the music is not too loud, and the service has been very good so far.  It has a high potential of becoming my standard neighborhood pub where I can go after work or hang out with friends on a quiet evening over a couple of nicely poured beers.. So far so good, I hope it doesn't turn into a big tourist stop for people going to Navy Pier.

Well, this was probably one of my most anticipated restaurant openings since Alinea.  Part of this is because every single day I walk by this place and I waited with baited breath for it to be open and me to have one more place closer to my house to reduce the drunken commute I often run into.   That being said- my expectations were high.  Very high. The service was really, really good.  But we were the only people in the place and there was a front and back waiter and a bus person.  It was such good service it was almost like we were in a fishbowl and they were watching us eat. Kind of creepy. The onion soup was possibly the best I have ever had(sorry mom) but my salad was small and kind of sad looking.  It made me wish i had ordered a side of fries instead.  The boyfriend had the D4 sandwich and he loved it.  Banger, kraut and Swiss cheese on bread.  A hungry man's delight. It is a really nice, clean looking place that is still putting the finishing touches on everything.  Definitely more of a pub atmosphere then a restaurant, the tables are not set up for long term dining. just long term drinking so you don't notice the discomfort factors.  And vegetarian's beware- this is a meat heavy menu and the salads are not really entree sized.  I will be interested in giving it a go for brunch.  They have a bunch of things that sound so fun that I have been raving about them pre opening for weeks.   Pigs in a blanket- two bangers wrapped in Swedish pancakes.  Love it.  Even if i will never eat it due to the bangers- it still makes me giggle. This is a great addition to the neighborhood and will definitely be a nice stomping ground for a drinking brunch or a Friday after work.  Just probably not for a lot of actual meals.  But who needs food with all the stout beers they have on tap!
